Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Guardian Angel-Enabling Mobile Safety Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
To date, safety services are typically constructed as dedicated stovepipe systems focusing on high reliability and a specific area of risk (e.g., automotive safety systems). Usage of  such services remains limited since they require a dedicated investment for each system. This project trades off the ultra-high reliability of dedicated systems for the much more  rapid adoption of safety services that comes with integrating them directly into mobiles and wearables. By demonstrating the feasibility of this approach, this project can contribute to saving lives, such as some of the more than 30,000 traffic fatalities in the United States each year. It can also inform regulatory policy for safety services  at the CPSC, NHTSA, or FCC. Moreover, the PIs will not only train graduate students to conduct the research but also actively include undergraduates and high school students through research internship programs. Results will be disseminated through scholarly publications, active outreach to the wireless and mobile industry through WINLAB's industry events and connections.

This project seeks to demonstrate that the mobile devices we carry and wear can provide effective safety services. This is particularly relevant where our devices contribute to dangers by causing distractions for drivers and pedestrians. This project therefore pursues the vision of a system that offsets such unsafe use by continually sensing our activities and surroundings, identifying potentially dangerous situations, and mitigating them through appropriate interventions. At a technical level, the primary challenge lies not only in designing precise sensing techniques but in understanding and managing the level of confidence provided by these techniques. A key observation is that there are usually multiple possible interventions of varying levels of intrusiveness and tolerance to false positives. It is therefore important to match interventions to the confidence level provided by the sensors. To address this challenge, the project develops system support and a toolkit to help developers track and manage mobile  sensing uncertainty. It explores crowdsourcing failure and relevance data  from a large user population and automatically estimating the confidence provided  by internal sensing and activity recognition components. The toolkit can further use the obtained metrics to help adapt sensing or application behavior. The system might conserve energy by switching one context sensor to a fallback mode from a diversity mode; or, the system could  switch to a different intervention if the level of confidence has changed. System validation includes prototyping two application use cases, which sense and mitigate mobile device distractions for drivers and pedestrians. Together, these techniques form the system, which supports development of many other effective safety services on mobile devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project seeks to demonstrate that the mobile devices we carry and wear can provide effective safety services as a Guardian Angel. This is particularly relevant where our devices contribute to dangers by causing distractions for drivers and pedestrians. This project therefore pursues the vision of a system that offsets such unsafe use by continually sensing our activities and surroundings, identifying potentially dangerous situations, and mitigating them through appropriate interventions. Particularly, we accomplished the following aspects: (1) early detection of abnormal driving behaviors using mobile sensors; (2) scaling road data acquisition for dependable self-driving; (3) developing pedestrian safety applications.

(1) Early Detection of Abnormal Driving Behaviors Using Mobile Sensors. Real-time abnormal driving behaviors monitoring is a corner stone to improving driving safety. Existing works on driving behaviors monitoring using smartphones only provide a coarse-grained result, i.e. distinguishing abnormal driving behaviors from normal ones. To improve drivers’ awareness of their driving habits so that to prevent potential car accidents, we consider a fine-grained monitoring approach, which not only detects abnormal driving behaviors but also identifies specific types of abnormal driving behaviors, i.e. Weaving, Swerving, Sideslipping, Fast U-turn, Turning with a wide radius and Sudden braking. We develop a fine-grained abnormal Driving behavior detection and identification system to perform real-time high-accurate abnormal driving behaviors monitoring using smartphone sensors. By extracting unique features from readings of smartphones’ accelerometer and orientation sensor, we first identify representative features to capture the patterns of driving behaviors. Then, a machine learning method is employed to train the features and output a classifier model which conducts fine-grained identification.

(2) Scaling Road Data Acquisition for Dependable Self-Driving. The proliferating driver assistance systems, especially the emerging autonomous driving technique offers a great opportunity to fuse the safety, efficiency and comfort of road travels. One of the most challenging problems in this technique is to understand not just common situations of highway and city traffic, but also the extremely diverse unusual events. Although such situations are rare, they represent significant risks that urge technology must address to develop truly dependable autonomous driving and traffic safety systems. By developing technology to scale road data acquisition to a large number of vehicles, this work introduces a low-cost yet reliable solution that can derive internal driver inputs (i.e., steering wheel angles, driving speed and acceleration) and external perceptions of road environments (i.e., road conditions and front-view video) using a smartphone and an IMU mounted in a vehicle. Results show that our system can accurately estimate steering wheel angles and vehicle speeds. The system also able to determine binary road conditions with high accuracy via a small number of brakes.

(3) Developing Pedestrian Safety Applications. Motivated by the safety challenges resulting from distracted pedestrians, our emphasis was on building a sensing technique for vehicle-pedestrian accident risk detection. The main focus of this activity is to detect when a pedestrian is at an increased risk of a traffic mishap. This requires the ability for fine-grained location classification to distinguish safe walking locations (such as sidewalks) and unsafe walking locations (such as streets). We further try to identify the pedestrian’s walking location by sensing the walking surface using foot mounted inertial sensors. These sensing techniques can be used to build safety application that warn either pedestrians or drivers.

The project offers great potential for broader impact both through the research topics that it addresses and through specific integrated educational and outreach activities. The Guarding Angel system once deployed could save numerous lives, given the more than 30,000 annual traffic fatalities in the United States alone. It could also inform regulatory policy at the CPSC, NHTSA, or FCC for safety services. Moreover, during the project period the PIs not only trained graduate students to conduct the research but also actively included undergraduates and high school students through research internship programs. Results are disseminated through scholarly publications, active outreach to the wireless and mobile industry through WINLAB's industry events and connections.
